page.title: 15 Radcot area landscape
page.content: Although on the edge of the Cotswolds this immediate area, being part of the Upper Thames Valley is quite flat. The fields alongside the river are liable to flood and careful maintainance of the banks is necessary. Being an area of mainly arable land it is composed of fields surrounded by hedgerows. The River Thames and belts of deciduous woodland add to the beauty of the area, electricity pylons however do spoil the view. The soil near the Thames is fertile silt but on the higher parts it is well drained red loam on gravel. Annual rainfall varies from 19ins to 27ins. The landscape lends itself to various sporting activities. Sheepdog trials are held annually at one farm; the Old Berks Hunt rides across the area and Radley College Beagles hunt for hares.
